About Work

BuzzFeed‚Äôs El Dashboard Suite

Building analytic tools to empower the organization to make data-driven decisions

Situation

BuzzFeed creates and publishes over 600+ videos, posts, and graphics a week to our owned & operated properties and many social platforms like Facebook or Snapchat. We get data back about how our content connects with our audiences from metrics like pageviews, shares, and minutes watched. The knowledge held in those data helps us to understand what resonates with our audiences, and as a result, powers the feedback loop ( Iterate ➝ Publish ➝ Learn ) for our content creators to make better, more engaging content.

Opportunity

Data plays an integral role in our editorial and advertising strategy. My team Reporting Tools (formerly Learning tools) was formed 2 years ago and tasked with this mission:

Empower the organization to make data-driven decisions with a suite of analytic tools that are hyper-focused and adaptable to meet the ever-changing needs of our organization, business and audiences.

My role

As the sole designer in the Reporting Tools team, I lead the design and execution of all the dashboards, push notifications, and product marketing collaterals. For the last year, I am the product manager in driving the strategy and vision for Audience Insights and Content Insights products.

Process

Although the user problems aren‚Äôt always the same, the process for each project is generally go ike this:

Define ⟶ Explore ⟶ Refine ⟶ Promote & onboard ⟶ Learn & Reflect

1 Define the problems by deeply understanding the user problems and business goals. The methodology and tools for this step include user/stakeholder interview, workflow/product audit, design sprint workshop, worksheets, thought exercises and journey mapping.

2 Explore the solutions in a broad spectrum to examine their viability, feasibility, and usability. With data products, I always prototype with real data to minimize speculative risks, suss out unforeseen uses cases and get genuine feedback from our users. I often use a mix of static (paper mocks, click-through screens) and live prototypes (live code, spreadsheet, 3rd party products.)

3 Refine the product and design to achieve the most effective and scalable solution. This is where we hone in on the details like pattern, interaction and affordance to make the information and interface are intuitive and effective.

To ensure our tools can grow gracefully, I establish a design system for the dashboard suites which includes the UI architecture, UI pattern, graph components and accessibility-friendly color palettes.

4 After shipping, we promote and onboard the new product or feature to our users in a 3-pronged strategy: in-app promotion (onboarding modal and promotional units), in-context announcement (Email and flyers) and in-person demo session. For our users in different time zones, we create thorough documentation like user guides, cheatsheets, and FAQs to help them get acquired with our tools on their own.

5 Learn and reflect after each product launch. We closely monitor the usage and collect users feedback to get improvement ideas for the future iteration. The team would gather for a retrospective to reflect on how the project went and identify the actions for improvement going forward.

Different Problems, Different Solutions

The user problems have evolved quite a bit in the last 2 years. Let‚Äôs start from the beginning.

üçû The Breadline Problem

Situation

The demand for data is higher than ever. Our data analysts were drowned by requests from different parts of the company and unable to keep up the demand. For the data consumers, accessing data was tedious. People spent more time hunting down data or cobbling stats from 3rd party tools and spreadsheets than making data analysis. Because of the high friction to access data, many people simply gave up or resorted to a subjective way to set goals and make decisions. There was no consistent way to measure content success that actually helps drive impact.

Objective

Making the most essential datasets accessible in an easy-to-use, well-organized design.

Solution

We developed a series of content insights dashboards to address those pain points by providing key metrics for a given piece of content. Given the high volume of data for content performance, the design goal for those products is to focus on efficiency and clarify. The table-based design powered by a set of robust filters, search and sorting, is efficient for exploring any large dataset. Users can look up ‚ÄúWhat are the most popular videos about B√©yonce?‚Äù and then drill down to dive into the detail stats.

List view dashboard shows a table of content based on selected paramenters such as time range, platform, location, creators, content type, language, etc.

Detail view is a "deep-dive" into a piece of content with granular metrics.

üôÖ Failed first attempt The first dashboard we built, known as the Content List, was based on an assumption that a one-size-fill-all product would satisfy everyone‚Äôs need. The generalized dashboard was too confusing for non-data savvy folks and too simplistic for power users. The unclear use case along with the unforeseen engineering challenge forced us to kill the dashboard shortly after its completion. Since then, our team learned to be critical of product decisions and evaluated every project by the user impact and team effort before design and development.

üö® The Signal Problem

Situation

As finding data about an individual piece of content became easier, our users started to wonder which insights are noteworthy and actionable: Is a 100K number of shares for a food video good or exceptional in the historical context? Which content shows an early signs of virality? What are the important "signal" we should act on and go after the success?" Noteworthy signal helps the content distribution team to fuel the popular content futher so they can promote them to other platforms, channels or countries. For our content creation team, they can learn from successful content and iterate on it for new ideas.

Objective

Surface noteworthy insights in real-time about outstanding and trending content to help our editorial team to capitalize their success further.

Solution

Create features and products that highlight exceptional and trending content in a strong visual way:

The 99 badges are the reward icons given to content that broke high benchmarks of certain metric. The strong visual icons are a key identifier that are implemented across different slack notifications and dashboards.

Trending Videos Dashboard is a visual hall-of-fame for videos that have the highest velocity in shares and Views growth. The treemap helps users to grasp the fastest growing content based on the size of the image.

‚öóÔ∏è Content Discovery and Experiment Problem

Situation

Most of the exceptional content and viral hits is a result of experimentation. However, discovering and tracking a group of content based on a topic, tag or intent remained very difficult. Editorial leads often resorted to a manual process to log the data into a spreadsheet and aggregate the result.

Objective

Facilitate the ideation and experimentation process by providing toolings to make tagging, searching and learning a grouping of content easier.

Solution

Create tools to help users to ideate and track experiment and through content discovery (Search), custom tagging (Experiment) and content intent analysis. (Jobs)

Search is a content discovery tool of 3.5+ millions of videos, graphics, and posts in the BuzzFeed‚Äôs catalog, so people can draw inspiration from all the green-tea dessert videos we have ever made in the past.

Experiment is a workflow tool for creating and applying custom tags to a group of content.

Cultural Cartography visualization is an experimental project to group content based on intent or "job-to-be-done".

Job chrome-extension allows content creator to tag any content in the browser.

‚ù§Ô∏è Platform Health Problem

Situation

Despite an easy access to data and detect outliers, our editorial still leads have a hard time tracking the overall health and long-term trends of our core distribution platforms, like BuzzFeed‚Äôs owned and operated and Facebook. The content consumption and our distributed platform are contstantly evolving, able to monitor our content outputs to maximize the returns in audience engagement becomes critical to our business.

Objective

Help our editorial management to monitor the health of the core distribution platforms by tracking the output and performance trends over time

Solution

Develop a health platform dashboard for Facebook and O&O (Owned & operated), our two main distribution platforms. The dashboard consists of time-series graphs that show content output and the key metrics side-by-side. All key metrics have a strong correlation with each other where a change in one metric could reveal a change in another. One of the novels features in all health dashboard is pinning. It let users to click and mark any date across all graphs so the user can compare the changes of those metrics across the same point in time.

2 years later...

While those big initiatives were happening, our team was also gradually expanding the dashboard suite by increasing our data coverage for the entire organization. Today, the dashboard suite, known as El Dashboard, has grown into a suite of 12 dashboards under four categories of tools: Content insights, Signal, Discovery & Experiment, and Platform Health.

Results

  • El Dashboard continues to grow and thrive as the core analytic tools for the company. With over 500+ active users a month, people reply on our tools to access data for making strateigic decision, reporting, and brainstorming every day. For each launch, we would got a swamp of email with positive reaction and occasional bug report like this:
  • The speed and user-friendless of El Dashboard has earned a good reputation within company. We recently expand our user base to support the business and advertising division (~200 users) . They have switched their old workflow to use our tools for creative pitch and ideation with brands. Even our business data analyst loves our product:
  • The dashboard enables our content creators to learn and experiment in a rapid pace so they can create engaging, shareable content one after another. One example is this video pf growing vegetable scraps which garnered 6.6M shares lead to many up-cycling videos the BuzzFeed audiences love and enjoy.

Role: Design Lead & product manager. Team: 5 engineers, 4 data scientists, 1 product manager, 1 product support.
